awd_titl_txt: Multi-Messenger Astrophysics with the Cherenkov Telescope Array
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma rays probe physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. Gamma-ray detectors may also be capable of observing cosmic rays, which are highly energetic sub-atomic particles that travel near the speed of light. The origins and acceleration mechanisms of cosmic rays are unknown but they likely originate in extreme astrophysical phenomena both within and beyond our galaxy. This award supports scientists at the University of Wisconsin in the development of hardware and analysis techniques for the next-generation gamma-ray telescope, the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA), an international gamma-ray observatory currently in the prototyping stage of development.  A new design, the Schwarzschild Couder Telescope, is currently under construction in Arizona at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory. This award will support the group's work on the camera for the telescope, including the data processing and analysis procedures for this prototype telescope. They will then test new methods for studying cosmic rays using the unique capabilities of this new instrument. The PI leads the Distributed Electronic Cosmic-ray Observatory (DECO), an education and outreach project that uses cell phones as particle detectors. This award will support the group to work with local teachers to develop lesson plans and projects to use DECO in classrooms.
 
The prototype Schwarzschild Couder Telescope uses silicon photo-detectors with new capabilities, including the ability to operate in moonlight conditions. The University of Wisconsin group will develop the data taking, processing, and analysis procedures for these new detectors. They will then characterize the instrument performance under moonlight conditions and study the cosmic-ray Moon shadow during partial Moon illumination. These studies will lay the groundwork for a measurement using CTA of the positron fraction using the opposite direction of the electron and positron shadows as deflected in the Earth's magnetic field.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to commission, calibrate, and develop operating procedures for a new type of ground based gamma-ray telescope, the prototype Schwarzschild-Couder Telescope (pSCT).  The telescope is used to detect gamma rays at the TeV scale, among the highest energy gamma rays in the universe.  The telescope builds on the heritage of similar ground-based telescopes that use single mirror dishes to collect Cherenkov light flashes from gamma rays colliding with the atmosphere.  However, this telescope is innovative in multiple ways.  First, it uses two mirror dishes rather than one to focus the light, which results in superior imaging resolution of the gamma-ray-induced air shower.  This enables superior background rejection and signal reconstruction, both of which translate directly into scientific capability.  Second, the camera uses silicon photomultipliers and custom electronics to record the light flash focused by the mirrors.  After completing commissioning and establishing the observing procedures, we recorded data from the Crab Nebula in 2020.  We used the data to develp calibration and analysis procedures for this new type of telescope.  Using the new telescope and procedures, we detected TeV-scale gamma rays from the Crab Nebula with 8.6 sigma statistical significance.  We published this work in the journal Astroparticle Physics.  This detection establishes our new telescope technology for very-high-energy gamma-ray astrophysics.  Future work, in particular using an expanded and upgraded camera, will build on this initial success to investigate the full potential of this new technology in terms of its scientific capabilities.  The upgraded telescope will also be used for scientific measurements and discoveries in coordination with VERITAS, an array of four telescopes co-located with the pSCT.  The SCT technology is proposed to be used to construct 10 or 11 telescopes for the Cherenkov Telescope Array, the next-generation gamma-ray observatory.  

 

In addition to work on the pSCT, this award supported work on the Distributed Electronic Cosmic-ray Observatory (DECO).  DECO is a citizen science project that uses the camera image sensor of smart phones to detect cosmic rays and other energetic particles.  DECO is focused on outreach and education but also has a research component and has several interesting scientific and technical synergies with CTA including the pSCT.  Both projects detect energetic particles produced by astrophysical processes, and both projects rely on analysis of images recorded by silicon radiation sensors.  This synergy has enabled students and scientists to apply lessons learned (and algorithms developed) in each project to the other.  We established that DECO detects cosmic-ray muons using their known zenith angle distribution, used that angular distribution to measure the active (depleted) thickness of the smart phone image sensors, and developed a computer vision algorithm to determine the identity of the particle in each image.  We published this work in one paper in the Journal of Instrumentation and one in the journal Astroparticle Physics.
